Essentially these courses assume print-based patterns of thought and behav¬
ior, as well as communication#
Each medium not only provides transportation but also patterns for
thoughts, as rigid in their deepest respects as railroad rails. These
patterns are imposed not only on educations in the lineally-devised text¬
books, c*sra»icula, and classrooms set up in rows, with student-by-student
recitation — but also on industry with its production lines. They tax
the ability of teachers and all others of us, who are the products of a
print-based education and culture system, to cope with non-lineal impressions
and messages.
In classrooms today, most teachers called upon to guide and control
uses of radio and television, do so as if these were merely extensions of
print and lineal methods and approaches based on print — or merely additions
to the tools available. Through no fault of their own, they are largely
unaware of the fundamental characteristics of media themselves, as media#
let profound and worried scholars have found that, in the case of
television for instance, the medium itself, without regard to content,
accounts for by far the largest part of its total effect# Scholars who have
studied monopoly-BBC uses, uses in the USSR, uses by commercial broadcasters
of the U# S#, and uses for education, find that television^ most profound
effects are common to all systems and uses, regardless and independent of
message, content, method, use, or intended effect# The most profound charac¬
teristics of media, as media, have not been recognized by American education
